pyclustkit.metalearning package

Submodules

pyclustkit.metalearning.cad module

class pyclustkit.metalearning.cad.CaD[source]

Bases: object

A class to calculate meta-features based on pairwise distance and spearman correlation.

cad(df)[source]

Calculates the meta-features from the distance-based vector, as per the Ferrari et al. 2015 paper.

Parameters:

df (pd.DataFrame) – The dataset at hand.

Returns:

A dictionary containing the meta-features.

Return type:

dict.

correlation(df)[source]

Calculates the meta-features from the distance-based vector, as per the Ferrari et al. 2015 paper.

Parameters:

df (pd.DataFrame) – The dataset at hand.

Returns:

A dictionary containing the meta-features.

Return type:

dict.

Calculates the meta-features from the distance-based vector, as per the Ferrari et al. 2015 paper.

pyclustkit.metalearning.cad.correlation_vector(X)[source]

Calculates the vector of pairwise distances of the dataset. Args (np.ndarray or pd.DataFrame):

The list of pairwise distances.

pyclustkit.metalearning.descriptive module

A collection of methods for various meta-features that fall into the descriptive category.

pyclustkit.metalearning.descriptive.pct_of_discrete(df)[source]

A method to find the percentage of columns that contain discrete values. Such columns are identified automatically

Parameters:

df (np.ndarray or pd.DataFrame) – The dataset

Returns:

percentage of columns with discrete values in the dataset

Return type:

float

pyclustkit.metalearning.descriptive.pct_of_mv(df)[source]

return the percentage of missing values in the dataset. :param df: The dataset. :type df: np.nd.array or pd.DataFrame

Returns:

in the range of (0,1)

Return type:

float

pyclustkit.metalearning.landmark module

A script that contains the method for calculating landmark meta-features, i.e. meta-features that derive from information provided after training a machine learning algorithm for the task.

class pyclustkit.metalearning.landmark.CVIMF[source]

Bases: object

calculate_cvi(x, cvi_name, algorithm)[source]
Parameters:

  • x (np.ndarray or pd.DataFrame) – The data to calculate meta-features

  • cvi_name (string) – Name of the CVI to calculate

  • algorithm (string) – Name of the algorithm that partitions data

Returns:

The CVI value calculated

Return type:

float

pyclustkit.metalearning.statistics module

pyclustkit.metalearning.statistics.hopkins(X: array, portion=0.1, seed=247) → float[source]

Implementation of the hopklins statistic to measure cluster tendency. Sample size is calculated according to heuristics based on : Validating Clusters using the Hopkins Statistic from IEEE 2004. If the data size is less than 100, sample size equals to the original data’s records.

pyclustkit.metalearning.statistics.kurtosis_of_pca_first_component(X)[source]
pyclustkit.metalearning.statistics.max_kurtosis_of_continuous(df: array) → dict | nan[source]

calculates the max kurtosis of continuous attributes

calculates the max skewness of continuous attributes

pyclustkit.metalearning.statistics.mean_absolute_continuous_feature_correlation(df: DataFrame) → float[source]

calculates the mean pairwise correlation of the given dataframe’s features. Currently, supports only Pearson’s correlation.

pyclustkit.metalearning.statistics.mean_concentration_between_discrete(df)[source]

df

float or NaN

pyclustkit.metalearning.t_squared module

pyclustkit.metalearning.t_squared.mv_normality_test(df)[source]

Calculates the percentage of values in the t_squared vector that are less than the critical value of the chi-squared distribution with degrees of freedom equal to the array’s number of instances.

pyclustkit.metalearning.t_squared.t_squared_outliers(df)[source]

Calculates the percentage of outliers according to the t_squared vector. In such case outliers are the values that are more than two standard deviations distant from the mean.

pyclustkit.metalearning.t_squared.t_squared_skewness(df)[source]

calculates the t_squared vector’s skewness.

pyclustkit.metalearning.t_squared.tsquared_transform(X: array)[source]

Calculates the t_squared transformed vector.
